segment.source: In Windows 10, Microsoft Passport replaces passwords with strong two-factor authentication that consists of an enrolled device and a Windows Hello (biometric) or PIN.
segment.target: In Windows 10, Microsoft Passport replaces passwords with strong two-factor authentication that consists of an enrolled device and a Windows Hello (biometric) or PIN.

segment.source: Microsoft Passport lets users authenticate to a Microsoft account, an Active Directory account, a Microsoft Azure Active Directory (AD) account, or non-Microsoft service that supports Fast ID Online (FIDO) authentication.
segment.target: Microsoft Passport lets users authenticate to a Microsoft account, an Active Directory account, a Microsoft Azure Active Directory (AD) account, or non-Microsoft service that supports Fast ID Online (FIDO) authentication.

segment.source: After an initial two-step verification during Microsoft Passport enrollment, a Microsoft Passport is set up on the user's device and the user sets a gesture, which can be Windows Hello or a PIN.
segment.target: After an initial two-step verification during Microsoft Passport enrollment, a Microsoft Passport is set up on the user's device and the user sets a gesture, which can be Windows Hello or a PIN.

segment.source: The user provides the gesture to verify identity; Windows then uses Microsoft Passport to authenticate users and help them to access protected resources and services.
segment.target: The user provides the gesture to verify identity; Windows then uses Microsoft Passport to authenticate users and help them to access protected resources and services.

segment.source: Microsoft Passport also enables Windows 10 Mobile devices to be used as a remote credential when signing into Windows 10 PCs.
segment.target: Microsoft Passport also enables Windows 10 Mobile devices to be used as a remote credential when signing into Windows 10 PCs.

segment.source: During the sign-in process, the Windows 10 PC can connect using Bluetooth to access Microsoft Passport on the user’s Windows 10 Mobile device.
segment.target: During the sign-in process, the Windows 10 PC can connect using Bluetooth to access Microsoft Passport on the user’s Windows 10 Mobile device.

segment.source: Because users carry their phone with them, Microsoft Passport makes implementing two-factor authentication across the enterprise less costly and complex than other solutions
segment.target: Because users carry their phone with them, Microsoft Passport makes implementing two-factor authentication across the enterprise less costly and complex than other solutions

segment.source: Benefits of Microsoft Passport
segment.target: Benefits of Microsoft Passport

segment.source: User convenience.
segment.target: User convenience.

segment.source: The employee provides credentials (such as account and password, or other credentials), and is then guided to set up Microsoft Passport and Hello.
segment.target: The employee provides credentials (such as account and password, or other credentials), and is then guided to set up Microsoft Passport and Hello.

segment.source: From that point on, the employee can access enterprise resources by providing a gesture.
segment.target: From that point on, the employee can access enterprise resources by providing a gesture.

segment.source: Security.
segment.target: Security.

segment.source: Microsoft Passport helps protect user identities and user credentials.
segment.target: Microsoft Passport helps protect user identities and user credentials.

segment.source: Because no passwords are used, it helps circumvent phishing and brute force attacks.
segment.target: Because no passwords are used, it helps circumvent phishing and brute force attacks.

segment.source: It also helps prevent server breaches because Microsoft
segment.target: It also helps prevent server breaches because Microsoft

segment.source: Passport credentials are an asymmetric key pair, which helps prevent replay attacks when these keys are generated within isolated environments of Trusted Platform Modules (TPMs).
segment.target: Passport credentials are an asymmetric key pair, which helps prevent replay attacks when these keys are generated within isolated environments of Trusted Platform Modules (TPMs).
